0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Glucose tolerance test: Diabetes mellitus (diagnosis): 75 g anhydrous glucose (dextrose) dissolved in water ORALLY, as one-time dose for oral glucose tolerance test
  • Glucose tolerance test: Gestational diabetes mellitus (diagnosis), one-step approach: 100 g anhydrous glucose (dextrose) dissolved in water ORALLY, as one-time dose for oral glucose tolerance test
  • Glucose tolerance test: Gestational diabetes mellitus (diagnosis), two-step approach: 50 g anhydrous glucose (dextrose) dissolved in water ORALLY as one-time dose for glucose challenge test, then perform the 100-g oral glucose tolerance test on those who exceeded the threshold value on the glucose challenge test
  • Intravenous feeding of patient: IV dose is dependent upon the age, weight and clinical condition of the patient

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Intravenous feeding of patient: IV dose is dependent upon the age, weight and clinical condition of the patient; particular caution in pediatric patients, particularly neonates and low birth weight infants

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Intravenous feeding of patient
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Deficiency of anterior cruciate ligament - Knee pain
  • Glucose tolerance test
  • Insulinoma
  • Oral rehydration therapy
  • Septic shock; Adjunct

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: simultaneous administration with blood through same infusion set; avoid due to possibility for pseudoagglutination of red cells (IV)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• diabetes mellitus, subclinical or overt; use with caution
  • potassium-free solution, excessive administration; may result in significant hypokalemia (IV)
  • fluid and/or solute overloading may occur, resulting in dilution of serum electrolyte concentrations, overhydration, congested states of pulmonary edema (IV)
  • pediatric patients, particularly neonates and low birth weight infants; increased risk of hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia; excessive or rapid infusion rate in very low birth weight infants may result in increased serum osmolarity and possible intracerebral hemorrhage (IV)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Endocrine metabolic:Hyperglycemia
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Injection site extravasation
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyperosmolarity, Hypervolemia
  • Neurologic:Cerebral hemorrhage, Cerebral ischemia
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary edema

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Dextrose solution provides a source of water and carbohydrate (340 kcal/L). The simple carbohydrate may minimize liver glycogen depletion and provide a protein-sparing action.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• adequate hydration and electrolyte balance are indicative of efficacy
  • changes in fluid balance, electrolyte concentrations, and acid-base balance; during prolonged parenteral therapy or when clinically warranted
  • blood and urine glucose
